title: Electrochemical Sensors in pharmaceutical and biomedical analysis (Electrosensors)
description:
In this teaching, we wish to introduce to the students the main electrodes (specific electrodes, oxygen sensor, glucose biosensor…) and the principles of the electrochemical methods used in the field of pharmaceutical and biomedical analysis. We consider to focus on the enzyme electrochemical biosensors, notably the glucose biosensor, and on the ion selective electrodes, e.g. calcium. These electrodes are used in the blood glucose and in the blood gas detections.

At the end of the course participants will:

- learn the basic processes of several biosensors, thermodynamics and kinetics of weak molecular interactions
- discover host-guest interactions of bioactive guest molecules with cavity-shaped hosts (cyclodextrins, calixarenes, cavitands, cucurbiturils) and their immobilization onto the glassy carbon or platinum electrode surfaces by electro-polymerization.

This course, offered at 4 European universities, brings together European students from different universities. This unique approach allows students to benefit from a truly international and intercultural learning experience.

Coordinators : Carla Caddeo (University of Cagliari), Karel Šmejkal (University of Masaryk)

title: European Union Law and Sustainable Development
description:
#### Learning objectives

This course proposes an overview of the integration of sustainable development into European Union law. The objective of a sustainable development, set out in the 1987 Brundtland Report and confirmed by the 1992 Rio Conference on Environment and Development, now infuses all European Union law. Regulations designed to protect the environment have been developed, but more broadly the issue of environmental protection has become an integral part of the law relating to economic activities.

At the end of the course, participants will:

- Master the concept of sustainable development and its implications for European law
- Be familiar with the general legal framework applicable to environmental matters at European level, the principles and the main sectoral regulations
- Understand the links with the international level and the obligations of the Member States of the European Union in environmental matters.
prerequisites:
- Master students 
- Basic knowledge on European Law / European governance   
- Open for all EDUC universities
details:
#### Details of the learning scenario

This course will give you access, in two possible ways, to the 6 sessions of 2 hours taught in the Master 1 Environmental Law at the University of Rennes:

**1- Remote access to live lectures:**

Session dates: Tuesdays 14/01, 21/01, 28/01, 04/02, 11/02, 25/02 from 5pm to 7pm.   

**2- Off-line access to audio recordings of the sessions** enriched with comprehension questions. 

Both these access options are available on the Moodle EDUC platform.

Please consider a work-load per week of: 3 hours

title: Research Internship - Biology Internship at CEITEC (Czech Republic)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
At least 3 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
No constraints

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**

CEITEC stands for Central European Institute of Technology, which is a multidisciplinary research centre with cutting-edge technologies. More info: https://www.ceitec.eu/ceitec-mu 


**Description of the tasks**

Cloning
Protein expression
Protein purification
NMR analysis


**Description of skills and competencies to be developed**

- Problem solving Knowledge of a foreign language 
- Ability to work in an interdisciplinary team 
- Ability to work in an international context 
- Ability to generate new ideas (creativity) 
- Understanding of cultures and customs of other countries

**Host organisation support: financial support**

Check with your home university if you are eligible for an Erasmus+ scholarship.

An experienced researcher from the group will supervise the intern in the lab.
Weekly meetings and progress reports with the Head of the Group.
Participate and present in group seminars.

**Application process**
Not listed

**Field of studies**
- Natural science/Biology

**Level of studies**
- Bachelor level 1
- Bachelor level 2
- Bachelor level 3
- Master level 1
- Master level 2

title: Research Internship - Environmental economics internship (Czech Republic)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
2 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
3rd March 2025

**Preferred end date**
5th May 2025

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**

Department of Regional Economics: https://www.econ.muni.cz/en/about-us/organizational-structure/561800-department-of-regional-economics ; https://www.econ.muni.cz/en/news/air-quality-in-brno-has-been-improving-but-it-is-still-far-from-ideal

**Description of the tasks**

Data Collection and Analysis
- Conduct comprehensive research using academic sources such as journal articles, books, and reports related to environmental economics, sustainability, and air quality and health issues.
- Collect and organize data on environmental indicators, such as air quality levels, carbon emissions, and other sustainability metrics, from both local and global sources.
- Analyze trends related to sustainability challenges, environmental impacts and sustainable practices.
Case Studies
- Conduct comparative studies of sustainable practices from other regions or countries
- Prepare reports highlighting best practices that can be applied locally

Developing Visual Materials
- Create visual representations of data and findings, including maps, charts, graphs, and infographics, using tools such as Microsoft Excel, Power BI, or GIS software

Departmental Engagement
- Participate in departmental meetings, seminars, or workshops, presenting internship progress and insights to faculty and peers.
- Collaborate with department members on specific research projects or assignments

Content Creation for Instagram:
- Develop visually appealing posts and stories highlighting key insights about tourism sustainability, trends, or case studies.
- Create infographics, short videos, or reels to engage a broader audience"

**Description of skills and competencies to be developed**
- Ability to analyse and synthesise 
- Problem solving 
- Ability in organising and planning 
- Teamwork 
- Ability to learn 
- Ability to apply knowledge in practice 
- Understanding of cultures and customs of other countries"

**Additional requirements**
Academic background in fields related to regional economics, economic geography, environmental sociology, sustainability, or a similar discipline.
Ability to work independently as well as part of a team, especially in a collaborative academic environment.

**Host organisation support: logistic support**

Provided by the host faculty at MU – the same as for other Erasmus+ internship students: services directly related to the university such as student card, orientation week, etc. If needed, accommodation assistance can be provided upon request.


**Host organisation support: financial support**

Check with your home university if you are eligible for an Erasmus+ scholarship.

**Host organisation support: mentoring conditions**

Weekly Check-ins: A structured 30-minute meeting every week to review progress, address challenges, and set goals for the upcoming week.
Regular work in the study room, collaboration with PhD students and on-demand support, 
Final Debrief: A comprehensive meeting at the end of the internship to discuss outcomes, evaluate deliverables, and provide feedback.

**Application process**
Not listed

**Field of studies**
- Social science  /  Economics
- Applied science  /  Environmental studies and forestry 
- Applied science  /  Public policy

**Level of studies**
- Bachelor level 1
- Bachelor level 2
- Bachelor level 3
- Master level 1
- Master level 2

title: Ethics and Integrity in Research
description:
#### Learning objectives

The development of a research career is accompanied by a range of issues that are not always easy to resolve. Ensuring the integrity of research processes, knowing where to publish results in accordance with open access principles, or complying with the ethical standards set by research funding agencies and publications are just a few examples of some of the issues that the research community must address. This course aims to provide some basic tools useful for the research community in the field of research ethics, focusing in particular on integrity, dissemination of results and ethics committees. 

The course provides both theoretical content and some useful practical guidance for the research community.
prerequisites: #### Be enrolled in an EDUC Alliance doctoral programme or be an EDUC Alliance academic or research staff member.
details:
#### Details of the learning scenario

The course will take place by means of synchronous classes requiring the participation of students. 
 
*3 February 2025*
3 to 4.30 pm: Scientific integrity and delimitation of common malpractice
4.30 to 4.45 pm: Break
4.45 to 6 pm: Open access, its different routes and the complex problem of predatory journals
summary: The development of a research career is accompanied by a range of issues that are not always easy to resolve.

title: Research and Gender Perspective
description:
#### Learning objectives

The aim of this course is to provide EDUC research staff with training to implement the gender perspective in their research in accordance with the provisions of Spanish Law 14/2011 on science, technology and innovation, Art. 33j, “measures for the inclusion of the gender perspective as a cross category in science, technology and innovation” and in the Horizon 2020 Programme (EU Regulation no. 1291/2013), Art. 16, "the effective promotion of equality between women and men and of the gender perspective in research and innovation will be guaranteed".
prerequisites: #### Be enrolled on a doctoral programme of the EDUC alliance.\n
details:
#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is asynchronous.
● From 10 February to 28 February 2025. Materials and discussion forum available in the Virtual Classroom.
● 28 February 2025. Multiple-choice test (online)
summary: #### Learning objectives\n\nThe aim of this course is to provide EDUC research staff with training to implement the gender perspective in their research.

title: Grant Proposal Writing - English
description:
#### Learning objectives

Successful grant proposal writing is a fundamental basis to fund a career in research. It is a complex undertaking and seems to be very demanding. In this workshop you will learn how to break the overall process into smaller and doable chunks.

At the end of the **workshop** participants will:
- develop your idea for a project into a sound work programme,
- match it to the requirements of the funding programme and
- facilitate the communication with the reviewer by presenting your complex ideas in an easy-to-understand way.

title: Sea & Cities: The Challenges of Urban and Transport Planning for Local Communities and Sustainable Tourism
description:
Dive into the challenges of regenerating coastal cities at the Sea & Cities Summer School. Explore the intersection of urban and transport planning in the vibrant city of Cagliari, Sardinia!

The Sea & Cities: The Challenges of Urban and Transport Planning Summer School offers BA/MA students and PhD candidates a unique opportunity to explore the complexities of planning and regenerating coastal cities. Through an interdisciplinary approach, participants will address the demographic, ecological, energy, and digital transitions that shape these urban areas, with a focus on the interaction between city ports and surrounding regions. The programme includes lectures, lab activities, field trips, and contributions from experts and local authorities.
prerequisites:
#### Learning offer addressed to:

Basic knowledge or interest on Urban and regional planning, Transport planning, Energy planning, Sustainable urban planning, Sustainable tourism and landscape planning, Circular city, 15-minute city, Sports city, Urban regeneration, Accessibility and sustainable mobility, Geography and spatial analysis techniques.

####  English level B1

title: Open science - New Ways to Visibility and Collaboration
description:
#### Learning objectives

The term “open science” refers to the complete opening up of the research cycle: from the initial idea for a research project, through the generation and analysis of data, to the publication of research results and their subsequent use.

At the end of the course participants will:
- get an overview of "Open Science"
- get to know your opportunities with Open Science
- reflect your research towards the future
- know possibilities and limits of Open Science

title: Scientific and Academic Writing
description:
#### Learning objectives

Develop a powerful focus in your writing – an infallible guide to developing the best structure, and effectively communicating your ideas to your target audience. We look at how to systematically improve the impact, clarity and accuracy of your chosen words. You will receive a toolbox of methods including a range of easily-applied ‘quick tips’ that will improve how seriously your ideas are taken.

In this course participants will learn:
- Appropriate levels of formality
- Tips for writing productivity
- Nailing the problem of structure
- Achieving a good ‘flow’ of ideas and expression
- Achieving impact by careful word choice
- Clarity, brevity and style of English
- Understanding the most common mistakes
- Hated words to avoid in your text

title: Publishing Journal Articles: Strategies for Success
description:
#### Learning objectives

It is essential for Ph.D. candidates and scientists to develop an impressive publication record. The publication of high quality journal articles is imperative in order to apply for jobs or for research grants, to communicate findings, and to define their reputation in the field. This “publish-or-perish” approach, however, may decrease the quality of the journal articles.

At the end of the course participants will:
- understand the “bigger picture” of academic publishingo 
- List key criteria for choosing a target journal
- Write the cover letter for their next manuscript
- Describe the stages of the peer review process and its variants
- Communicate effectively with editors and reviewers during the publication process
- Recognize and avoid common unethical practices in academic publishing

title: Poster Power: Designing & Delivering with impact
description:
#### Learning objectives

A guide to the essential steps to designing a powerful, memorable poster. What has visual impact – and what to avoid. Practical, easy-to-apply tips to create a high standard of output. Quick wins for getting the best out of PowerPoint to obtain a professional finish. 

Day three of the course follows one week after the first two days of tutorial and is a ‘mini conference’ where you have a chance to present your re-designed poster for feedback and give a brief practice presentation.

At the end of the workshop participants will know:
- How to write and edit text length to create the optimum design
- How to create an appropriate, balanced layout
- Principles of ‘Grid Design’
- PowerPoint techniques and brief top tips tutorial
- How to use imagery and effective title block design
- Presentation of data and infographics
- Use of colour and colour choice
- Live and online poster presentation
- Interactive and animated presentation of static posters

title: AI Tools – Responsible Use & Applications in Academia
description:
#### Learning objectives

This workshop provides a hands-on learning experience with a focus on a wider variety of AI tools, their ethical implications and their practical applications. The aim is to facilitate the responsible and efficient use of AI tools in research and academia.

At the end of the workshop participants will:
- understand the importance of using AI in research and academia and assess the benefits and risks involved
- be able to craft effective prompts for their research tasks
- know how to develop strategies to integrate AI tools into their research workflow
 - be able to stay informed about and adapt to new developments in the field of AI

title: How to get into the (non-academic) German job market!
description:
#### Learning objectives

In the online workshop, international (post-)doctoral scholars planning to enter the nonacademic job market will learn key strategies for entering the job market, whether it be in business, society, culture or the public sector, and will be encouraged and empowered to put these into practice.

In this workshop participants will:
- get advice on how to identify useful contacts to approach for their job search
- learn how to identify suitable jobs and build their professional network
- identify their key competencies relevant for the non-academic job market
- practise articulating and evidencing their competencies briefly and succinctly
- prepare to be ready for networking chats or interviews
- will learn what makes a good application
- receive feedback on their own applications
prerequisites: #### Offer for PhD, Postdocs, PhD Supervisors, Researchers\n\n#### Course fee for EDUC applies, check under application link

title: Grant Proposal Writing - German
description: #### Learning objectives\n\nSuccessful grant proposal writing is a fundamental basis to fund a career in research. It is a complex undertaking and seems to be very demanding. In this workshop you will learn how to break the overall process into smaller and doable chunks.
prerequisites: #### Offer for Tenure Track professors, junior professors and postdocs\n\n#### Course fee for EDUC applies, check under application link
details:
#### Details of the learning scenario

The course is designed as a workshop consisting of 4 **synchronous** sessions (3.5 hrs each) in online format. 

Please consider a total work-load of 15 hours.


#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

**Day 1:** Tuesday, 04/03/2025, 9:00 - 12:30  
**Day 2:** Wednesday, 05/03/2025, 9:00 - 12:30  
**Day 3:** Wednesday, 19/03/2025, 9:00 - 12:30  
**Day 4:** Thursday, 20/03/2025, 9:00 - 12:30

title: Open Mindset - From Rivalry to Collaboration
description:
#### Learning objectives

In science, effective ways of interdisciplinary and international cooperation are increasingly in demand. The scientific culture is often still characterized by competitive thinking and it is necessary to question the extent to which this is still sustainable under resource pressure and simultaneously high quality requirements. New ways of thinking and new approaches are required.

At the end of the workshop, participants will:
- go from fixed to growth mindset
- learn to influence your thinking
prerequisites:
#### Offer for PhD, Postdocs, PhD Supervisors, Researchers

#### Course fee for EDUC: 50 €#### Course fee for EDUC applies, check under application link
